LEAD: Zambia, which has one of Africa's largest debt burdens, was granted relief on $2.4 billion of its debt last week at a meeting of its creditors in Paris, Finance Minister Gibson Chigaga said today.
Zambia, which has one of Africa's largest debt burdens, was granted relief on $2.4 billion of its debt last week at a meeting of its creditors in Paris, Finance Minister Gibson Chigaga said today.
Mr. Chigaga said $1.9 billion of the reduction was in past-due debt owed to the Paris Club of creditor nations. The remainder is interest due on debts until the end of 1991, he said.
He said Zambia's remaining debt, which he estimated at $7 billion, was owed mainly to Eastern European countries. He said they would be asked for similar terms of debt reduction.
At a meeting in Paris last week sponsored by the World Bank, 11 countries and five multilateral agencies raised aid to Zambia this year to $500 million, an increase of $50 milliion.
